main event: A round object, larger than a star, was observed moving up and down and north and south for 25 minutes on July 6, 1956.
interesting points: The object was larger than a star and had erratic movements, leading to the conclusion that it could be a heavenly body or affected by atmospheric conditions.
The observation lasted for 25 minutes, providing a significant duration for studying the object's behavior.
The color of the object was noted as an important factor, possibly due to the binocular viewing causing apparent movements.
The report suggests the possibility of the object being a heavenly body, but its color and erratic movements classify it as unidentified.
The sighting was made by a civilian using binoculars, adding credibility to the observation.
sighted object: round object, larger than a star, moving erratically
